metadata.case_name: AL. PR. Ranganathan Chettiar v. AL. PR. AL. Periakaruppan Chettiar
metadata.case_number: Civil Appeals Nos. 104 of 1954 and 169 of 1956

facts.text: AL. PR. Periakaruppan Chettiar (Periakaruppa) owned and possessed considerable properties.
Periakaruppa adopted AL. PR. Alagappa Chettiar (Alagappa) in or about 1914.
Acute differences arose between Periakaruppa and Alagappa from about 1924 due to Alagappa's alleged wasteful habits and debts.
Criminal complaints filed between Periakaruppa and Alagappa in 1926 (Exs. P-5 and D-12).
One of Alagappa's creditors obtained decree and attached Alagappa's half share in family residential house including site.

Suit regarding whether site was ancestral and superstructure built from ancestral funds; Madras High Court held on November 19, 1926, site ancestral, superstructure Periakaruppa's self-acquisition (Periakarappan Arunachalam, 1926 I.L.R. 50 Mad. 582).
Periakaruppa purported to adopt second son AL. PR. Ranganathan Chettiar (Ranganatha) on June 27, 1926, claiming custom in Nattukottai Chetti families.

Alagappa and his minor son AL. PR. AL. Periakaruppan Chettiar (junior Periakaruppa), represented by mother Muthayi Achi, filed O.S. No. 114 of 1926 on September 9, 1926, for half share of properties as joint family properties and declaration second adoption invalid.

Suit O.S. No. 114/1926 compromised by Rajinama on August 15, 1927, by four Panchayatdars: Rs.75,000 each to Alagappa and junior Periakaruppa, Rs.14,000 to Muthayi Achi as Stridhan; properties admitted self-acquisitions of Periakaruppa, no rights to plaintiffs, vacate family house, withdraw Privy Council appeal; certified for minors' benefit.
Payments made via four hundis on Nattukottai Chetti bankers in Burma.
Periakaruppa executed will on April 4, 1929; genuineness not disputed.
Periakaruppa died on July 14, 1929; wife Lakshmi Achi died March 11, 1930.
Will provided religious gifts, charities, management; residue to wife for life, then to Ranganatha.
Ranganatha attained majority around Lakshmi Achi's death in 1930; in undisputed possession till 1944.
Junior Periakaruppa attained majority December 1943.
Junior Periakaruppa filed O.S. No. 156/1944 (trust suit) and O.S. No. 164/1944 (succession suit) on November 11, 1944, in Subordinate Judge, Devakottai.

Trust suit (O.S. 156/44): Rs.75,000 under Rajinama constituted trust for junior Periakaruppa's benefit during minority under trusteeship of Periakaruppa and Chockalingam; wrongly appropriated by Chockalingam.
Succession suit (O.S. 164/44): Recover entire properties from Ranganatha; adoption invalid, will ineffective; devolves on junior Periakaruppa and Alagappa; not time-barred due to minority.

Both lower courts found adoption proved as fact but invalid due to no custom; trial court dismissed succession suit as time-barred under s.7 Limitation Act; High Court reversed, decreed half share to junior Periakaruppa (Alagappa's barred), held Rajinama caused division inter se.
In trust suit, Rs.30,000 invested in house purchase July 23, 1928, at Athangudi; family living there; credit given; other contentions negatived; decree against Ranganatha for half loss.
High Court judgments against Ranganatha; appeals to Supreme Court: CA 104/1954 by special leave Art.136, CA 169/1956 by certificate Art.133(1)(a).

legal_issues.text: Whether the adoption of Ranganatha was valid (found invalid, not disputed in SC).
Whether Periakaruppa's will was effective to vest title in Ranganatha notwithstanding invalid adoption; whether disposition to Ranganatha as persona designata or dependent on valid adoption.

If will ineffective, whether properties devolved on Alagappa alone excluding junior Periakaruppa or on both; whether Rajinama caused division inter se; applicability of s.7 Limitation Act 1908 to junior Periakaruppa.
In trust suit, whether Rajinama constituted Periakaruppa and Chockalingam as joint trustees for Rs.75,000 for junior Periakaruppa; whether Periakaruppa liable for breach of trust.

petitioner_arguments.text: Will effective; Ranganatha takes as persona designata, not dependent on valid adoption.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Nidhoomoni Debya v. Saroda Pershad Mookerjee (1876 L.R. 3 I.A. 253); Fanindra Deb Raikat v. Rajeshwar Das (1884 L.R. 12 I.A. 72)

petitioner_arguments.text: If will ineffective and Rajinama caused division inter se, properties devolved on Alagappa excluding junior Periakaruppa.
High Court erred; Rajinama did not bring divided status inter se between Alagappa and junior Periakaruppa; suit barred by s.7 Limitation Act.
No trust created under Rajinama; Periakaruppa not trustee; 'order' means maral (supervision), not control; no proof of usage; acted by guardians.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Negotiable Instruments Act ss.13,8,9,78; local usage cases

respondent_arguments.text: No effective dispositive clause in will; disposition creates estate in tail-male invalid; dependent on valid adoption which failed.
Rajinama caused division inter se; s.7 Limitation Act inapplicable; Alagappa de facto manager but irrelevant.

Rajinama constituted Periakaruppa and Chockalingam joint trustees for Rs.75,000; to invest in Chetti firms; 'order' gives control as per Negotiable Instruments Act; breach by investment in Chockalingam's firm.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Negotiable Instruments Act, 1881 s.13 Expl.III, ss.8,9,78

court_reasoning.text: Will effective; Ranganatha takes residue as persona designata, not conditional on valid adoption; inspired by experience with Alagappa; testator conscious of challenge to adoption; character over status; overall picture and background.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Validity of adoption not condition for disposition; Periakaruppa intended exclusion of Alagappa and heirs.

court_reasoning.text: Since will effective, no need to consider devolution, division inter se, or limitation.

Rajinama and hundi read together; 'order' not proved as giving absolute control to Periakaruppa and Chockalingam; means supervision (mel parvu), not management or operation; contemporaneous acts show Chockalingam handled under guardians' authority; Periakaruppa not involved in actings; no trusteeship on Periakaruppa.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No ipso facto legal ownership or control vested; deposit receipt not negotiable instrument.

holdings.text: Periakaruppa's will effectively disposed residue to Ranganatha as persona designata notwithstanding invalid adoption.
Rajinama did not constitute Periakaruppa as trustee for Rs.75,000; no liability for breach.

outcome.summary: Both appeals allowed with costs throughout; succession suit (CA 169/1956) and trust suit (CA 104/1954) dismissed; Ranganatha holds title under will; no trust liability on Periakaruppa's estate.

key_quotes.text: "Ranganatha notwithstanding his description as adopted son in the will in several places, was intended by the testator to take the property as persona designata"
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "All the immovable and movable properties entirely, which belong to me as my own and which are in my possession are my self-acquired properties. Excepting myself no other person has any interest or right whatever in the said properties."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "the aforesaid two persons shall be in management." (official translation of Tamil clause in Rajinama)
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Interpreted as supervision, not control for trusteeship.
